newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Army helicopter crashes, eight killed.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Army helicopter crashes, eight killed.

text.p: An Army helicopter crashed on Tuesday at Fort Bragg, killing eight soldiers, Army officials said.
The chopper went down in a wooded area near the southwest corner of the sprawling base about 20 miles (32 km) west-southwest of Fayetteville.
The victims were members of the elite 82nd Airborne Division, one of the U.S. military's top contingency groups called into battle at a moment's notice.
"An Army UH-60 Blackhawk helicopter crashed ... on Fort Bragg about 2:15 p.m. today, killing eight soldiers of the 82nd Airborne Division," the Army said in a statement.
"The names of the soldiers will be released after next of kin have been notified," the statement added. There was no immediate indication of what might have caused the crash.
The crash scene was cordoned off and military police directed traffic as work crews hauled floodlights and electrical generators into place.
The area of Fort Bragg where the chopper went down is open to the public and its roads are used by commuters, who were routed around the crash scene.
A heavy rainstorm swept through in late afternoon, muddying the site as investigators got to work. Fort Bragg's commander, Lt. Gen. Jack Keane, arrived to direct the recovery operation.
Corp. Carol Diggs, a public affairs officer for the 18th Airborne Corps, said an explosion and fire occurred as the helicopter crashed. Witnesses reported heavy smoke at the scene.
In March 1994, an Air Force F-16D jet fighter and a C-130 Hercules transport carrier were involved in an airborne collision at Pope Air Force Base, adjacent to Fort Bragg.
That crash killed 24 soldiers and injured at least 100 other military personnel.
